Situation1: They openly turn to each other for help in a difficult personal moment.
Situation2: The passenger is heading to a casual meeting with plenty of time
Story: My phone buzzed just as I pulled up to the curb for my next fare. It was my younger brother, his name flashing on the screen. I hesitated, knowing he only called when he really needed me. I answered, and his voice was shaky—he’d just had a fight with his best friend and needed to talk, maybe even see me. I glanced in the rearview mirror at my passenger, a woman scrolling through her phone, relaxed, in no rush for her casual lunch. As a sister, I felt the pull to be there for my brother, to listen, to comfort him like I always had. But as a taxi driver, I was expected to get my passenger safely and promptly to her destination, no detours, no distractions. My heart pounded as I weighed the responsibility of my job against the bond I shared with my brother. I gripped the steering wheel, torn between the urge to turn the car around and the duty to keep driving.
